title: If These Walls Could Talk: 3 Aussie Homes with Creepy Pasts
text:
It’s not just the dressed-up spectres we should be aware of around Halloween, sometimes it’s the unknown histories of the homes in which we live that cause the biggest fright.

It’s that time of year again when the ghouls and ghosts take over our neighbourhoods in the form of trick or treaters, waiting to scare you with their costumes before demanding sweets.

But for some of us, if we were to look deeply into the past of our own homes, the truth would be stranger than fiction. Potentially, if the walls of our own homes could talk, it might be a dark and bloody tale they’d tell.

In Australia, real estate agents are required to disclose to buyers if a house has been the site of a recent crime. But, it’s the creepy backstories in times gone by that might surprise you.

We’ve enlisted the help of Carly Godden, historian, and host of the Dead & Buried podcast, to help dig up the creepy and colourful pasts of some Aussie homes.

1. A gangster murdered by accident at an all-night jazz party

Where: Blakeney Street, Highgate Hill QLD

In the early hours of Sunday 20th December 1926, revellers at a late-night jazz party in Highgate Hill Brisbane were disturbed by William Kirby, an underworld gangster who went by the alias William ‘Spider’ Raper.

Described by tabloid newspaper Truth as “a terrorising influence with a thirst for gore,” William worked the Spring Hill area as a conman, extortionist and pimp.

The white picket-fenced property on Blakeney Street, a “quiet, out-of-the-way thoroughfare,” in the “scattered, rambling locality known as Highgate Hill,” was the home of his former-girlfriend Vera Meskall.

One night, after overhearing screams outside the home, a 29-year-old boarder named George Ward tried to intervene as William attempted to strangle Vera for refusing to give him money.

Following a struggle, William ripped out a fencepost and beat George with it, allowing him to force Vera inside.

Through the ajar door, George fired a warning shot down the corridor, which struck William and killed him.

The next day George turned himself in to the police reportedly declaring “I did not mean to do it.” He was tried for murder in the Brisbane Supreme Court but a jury took only 20 minutes to find him not guilty.

2. Death of a former circus dwarf following stabbing by tin opener

Where: Charles Street, Woolloomooloo NSW

On the morning of 4th February 1944 retired circus clown, Bob Widgery was found in the gutter opposite his home on Charles Street, Woolloomooloo. He had deep wounds to his neck and later died at Sydney hospital.

Born a dwarf, Bob had been a headline act who the Arrow newspaper reported possessed a “wit and repartee that seemed to be boundless.”

His death had been preceded with a raucous all-day party fuelled by “cheap wine” at his two-storey Victorian terrace. When the stock of wine ran out, one of the guests reportedly pawned her false teeth to purchase a fresh supply. Now that’s dedication!

The police suspected that Bob met his end at the hands of 42-year old coal lumper John Kirkadly who stabbed him with a tin opener during a drunken brawl.

John once shared a room with Bob and described him as a “quarrelsome man”. However, the prosecution did not commit him to trial, apparently due to a lack of evidence.

3. Shooting at the hands of a jealous lover while the husband slept inside

Where: Shakespeare Street Carlton VIC

On 15 April 1922, Mary Skelton was living with her husband William Skelton in Shakespeare Street when she was shot by her ex-lover, George Quigley.

Months previously Mary had been staying with her sister when she commenced an affair with George, however, she eventually broke it off.

On the evening of Good Friday, George showed up at the back door of the Skelton’s home in the hope of persuading Mary to take him back. She refused to even see him and a struggle ensued.

Suddenly Mary felt a sharp sting in her arm and saw blood.

At trial, one of the neighbours reported hearing a gunshot and the voice of a man saying, “There’s no harm done. It’s a pity it didn’t settle you.”

George was found guilty of unlawful wounding and sentenced to 12 months in jail.

About Dead & Buried

Dead & Buried is an award-winning podcast showcasing the hidden history and true crime stories from Melbourne and beyond. Hosts Carly Godden and Lee Hooper explore dark, intriguing tales of the misfits and radicals who once inhabited our homes, pubs, streets and laneways.
